DoYxtWegOwoWDKRd-griew.text: Shoryu is probably still in my book as the best place for ramen in London. Although, I do not feel it taste as good as it use to do - when it only had one shop in Regent Street. However, if friends ask me where to have ramen in London then Shoryu will be my recommendation!Carnaby street branch menu was slighly different, as they had the King Tonkotsu (£15). This consisted of extra noodles, char siu and King prawn. This is good for those who are hungry or want some thing a bit more filling than the normal ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. King Tonkotsu

yEW0YBSGogD6VvguIUXbQA.text: Always really packed, a great effort is needed to be seated. But the yummy yummy ramen is worth the hassle. Great sake choices as well.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom

fEIpDpezZb01T9XAmAhzSQ.text: Kingly court is now a really lively place with lots of outdoor tables in the courtyard. They gave done a great job filling it up with all types of eateries, bringing in a vibrant evening crowd. Shoryu was buzzing when we were there. A short queue unless you sat st the bar. The bar is a bit squashed but just fine if you want a quick bowl of noodles. We had the ramen of course. So wanted to love it. The soup was quite porky, noodles were not quite springy enough but adequate. At close to £10 a bowl, it's pricey. All in all, it's not love, but just a like.

0eVahN7VvXdAHk20lNBduw.text: I have no idea when or where Shoryu came from, but when they arrived, they arrived fast, widespread, and with a lot of hype. Some of it is justified, but I'm sure there's better ramen out there if you want to find it - maybe from an independent little Japanese restaurant - or Bone Daddies (even more hype!) but Shoryu is still definitely a good choice. I have counted 6 Shoryu locations in the Soho, Piccadilly, and Leicester Square area - 4 of which, including this one, are within walking distance of one another. The advantage of the Carnaby location is you can enjoy the outdoor seating of Kingly Court if you are so inclined... if the weather isn't perfect, the ramen will soon warm you up! So for something so sudden and widespread in the area, I was expecting mass-produced bowls of "ok" ramen - but it was very tasty. The authentic egg-on-top really added richness and was the best part, and the broth at the end was oh-so-good and warming, as ramen should be. The meat... well, I had their "classic" pork and whilst it tasted alright, it wasn't amazing, and I felt like I should have had more meat, and/or more noodles, for the £12 price tag my bowl came with. We started with chicken karaage and gyoze, both of which were fantastic and we wish we had ordered more (perhaps one each) than trying to share - but again we were trying to be thrifty.It wasn't unsatisfactory by any means, but I've had better in both quantity and value-for-money. However, I certainly haven't had better in the area, and my colleagues swear by it - it's a great place for our teams to grab a business lunch and have a chat over a hot bowl of soup. It's a good spot for lunch, and indeed if you are in the area, there's almost certainly a Shoryu around the corner!

1m0CsbeB0F60ARMd97NU-A.text: Went in for the soft launch and as I'm no stranger to the Shoryu empire, I took this opportunity to branch out in my ramen ordering. Went with the yuzu instead of the takana tonkotsu which grew on me, it's a spicy lemon-peppery chutney paste that gives this one a kick. If you're feeling in the mood for something different, give it a try! A pork hirata bun is always a good choice and we tried a few cocktails (happy hour 5-7 £5 cocktails).. give the umushu royal and gekkaikan smash a try if you're feeling plummy- the umushu royal is a nice citrusy pre-dinner fizz and the smash is great for after. They've also got frozen topped Kirin! Now I just need it to be hot outside!A few quirks for opening night with service but the food was great. I'm happy to see more ramen places taking over London.

VCbQ2v4IzdHeeofQbx4Ybw.text: Perfect place to come on a rainy London day! Shoryu has a few locations around London but the Kingly Court location is definitely the cutest. During the day this location normally has a line out the door but my friend and I arrived late on a Sunday evening and were seated right away. We started with the pork belly bao which were phenomenal and both got ramen afterwards. The bao were really hearty portions and I honestly could have been content with one of those and another appetizer. But... since we came for the Ramen it seemed inappropriate to skip out on their specialty. I had the traditional house ramen which was very good. The egg was cooked well and they did not skimp on the other toppings. Next time I would try the thicker noodles and maybe the vegetarian ramen to switch it up.

ZxKe7scW5C4EgOTtUYIYHQ.text: LOVE their Dracula Ramen and Pork Buns -- beyond delicious. Stumbled in here on a rainy night -- and am glad I did! Long wait times at Shoryu if you don't come early or sit at the bar. Sitting at their bar is great though -- didn't feel cramped or rushed. They have wonderful drinks -- can't emphasise that enough -- I had a Japanese Mojito with Kumquats -- was delicious. The service is fast and friendly. I appreciate the friendly service. I've found that other restaurants in this area are too focused on being "cool" and can't back up the food quality. Shoryu is the real deal..cool and great food.

sDLEdwVYhLvDl98PA6yhYQ.text: Like most restaurants in London, the interior design and ambience are spectacular, but the food is typically a disappointment. The ramen here was bland and lacked depth. It was a chore having to eat less than half of my ramen. I've been spoiled with really great ramen in California and Japan, so my expectations are high.

xsYTJPJ-wgepgK47BWOLaQ.text: I'm sorry Shoryu, but you and I, we must part our ways. There was a time when I truly loved you and we have had beautiful times together, mostly with your beautiful eggs which are still beautiful but I can't judge on eggs alone anymore.Teresa C and I wanted to try the new Shoryu opening in Carnaby, and to be quite frank, I was super apprehensive because I had such bad service at the Denman branch so this is their chance to redeem themselves really. It didn't. First things first, Taking bookings for the busiest nights in Carnaby where its a shopping event? it's not like they didn't know, they had a 20% off for that event! The queue wasn't handled effectively- empty tables sometimes, and not using their head to seat bigger tables. Here's a tip from a former waitress- you gotta stop thinking in a linear way. Seating people in a restaurants- you gotta think tactically! This was why I gave a crappy rating last time, I never got the attitude that they wanted me there, as a paying customer. Secondly the food, my first experience of Shoryu, I was blown away and I've brought my friends and family back and everything. The ramen wasn't wow like the flagship branch, the soup wasn't wow, there wasn't any depth. Also, we ordered a side dish at the same time as the mains and it hadn't even arrived even after we finished our ramen. We even asked for it a number of times. We were not impressed. When it finally came, what sounded on the menu sounded great, it was chisou tempura chicken with matcha salt. In practice, it's like they did that 80s thing with stuffing a chicken breast which dries it out then deep fried it. Not good. Also, the matcha salt was lost on it. I wanted to give it another star because I'm loyal, but honestly, it only deserves one. I'm really really disappointed that the last two times I went the service was truly truly atrociously bad.

ps_E0b1GSm6Z2B3Icf2H4g.text: I went with my partner for a lovely dinner date and my vegan Natural Bowl was incredible! Will be back for sure!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. Natural Bowl

D_u_N1yzW3K3geWneWJlpg.text: It is sad to think that there are so limited choices of ramen places in London.Shoryu is a great choice given the limited choices... ramen is really just a-ok or even below average if you know what the real ramen is about...  the soup lacks depth of flavour and the most importantly, the temperature which the soup is served is way too low...  and noodles are too sticky - sign on not draining the cooking water well enough...  but I put three star as it has wide enough choices outside of ramen so if you are not Japanese and not looking for a 5 minute ramen experience, this could be a good Japanese place to have a few munches..Try at least once and see it yourself - it is definitely worth the try.

KgntoubjSa3m7mdne3PGRQ.text: Deep, rich broth and moist and tender meats, it's comforting, delicious and everything you want from a bowl of steaming ramen.  I had the karaka tan tan tonkotsu, which hit all the right notes on flavour and spice.  Since Ittenbari has taken a turn for the worse, this is now my go to ramen place.  I would have given 5 stars for the ramen alone but the service is lackluster (their waiters just don't seem very bright either that or their personalities have been beaten out by some corporate policy) and the hakata iced chicken left me very cold... It was like eating leftover chicken right out of the fridge.  The ramen though is the bomb!

utNP0Gt1E2m4FsmmmE93kQ.text: We traveled over 5 countries in Europe and we had the best service here. Ramen was good too.

oaHE4rYmCwhTGT7vwZW_KQ.text: Expensive for what it was, especially the sides like the soft shell crab. Ramen was average but cocktails were good, especially during happy hour!

EGDHw9gdGQUSQnx5uag6og.text: Incredible food - actually the best dim sum I've ever had. And the drinks for central London were very reasonable!

WzvXf8fWgcIPiuq22WvUfQ.text: Knowing the passion of Executive Chef Kanji Furukawa and the professionalism of Head chef Andy and his well trained kitchen team,this restaurant is a great choice for every Ramen lover! The passion it's in their bones :)

hwQ37ownmGqHeMkkTRmsxQ.text: Shoryu is a good place for ramen around SOHO. The pork in their ramen is amazing but the noodles are so-so. Everything is like a ok level but not fantastic.

HEql8rYryJmLmaaFnyqsWA.text: Although the food was good. The service by one particular woman was awful. The Japanese waitresses were very polite and nice but the other waitress was awful. We felt rushed and the meal took long to arrive. As we ate outside on the edge of the outdoor heaters, we asked another waitress if we could move into the centre under the heaters once the people occupying the space finished eating and left because we were cold. She politely said "of course". We were worried that someone would quickly be allocated to the seats so once they left we moved our plates to the new area. The rude waitress came up to us and made a total scene telling us in her exact words "Girls this is not how we work, we need to clean up first, you cannot sit here." It was in a very condescending manner and was so embarrassing. I appreciate that they have to clear the table but if we had to wait and ask again the table would have been taken as it was a very busy day. All she had to do was clear it up and not make a big deal. For this reason I refused to pay service charge and they knew why.

hXLPM-_AvaBaqlciuVPH6A.text: I came here last night as I've heard good things about it and was not impressed at all. There were lots of waitresses just walking around looking like they didn't know their place, asking how things were going at the most inappropriate times (while I was literally chewing or drinking) and some couldn't really speak English (they were not Japanese but east European I believe). There's an Italian girl who I believe to be the team leader and she was really nice and professional. The ramen was pretty bland (we tried two different varieties) and cannot be compared to real ramen. We also ordered a sharing platter which, at £12 I expected to be a bit more satisfying (three pieces of tasteless tempura and fried chicken, with something that looked like seaweed salad but turned out to be spinach). I was not impressed by this experience, everything was pretty flavourless and lacked authenticity. I will not be back.

vHV0VZkEuxgzwSiyl7fkMQ.text: You know who they are, the hungover shadows faintly smelling of Vodka Redbull and last night's sweat who don't have the energy for a home-cooked meal, but have somehow managed to maintain the self-worth needed not to call up Dominoes. It's these people, and the broken-hearted, the disenfranchised, the walk-of-shame creatures of central London that Shoryu cooks for.Because there is no way anyone could have come up with this thick, milky broth and noodle pot, the crunchy shallots on top, the pork belly crispy but not overpowering, the eggs runny and gelatinous like the inside of a Sharon Fruit, if not to mend souls and pull people back from the brink of death. You will never know peace, calm or fulfillment till their Tonkotsu. You will never know the capabilities of your taste buds till their famous pork buns. Just go here and allow the Kotteri Hakata noodle soup inside of you, one noisy slurp at a time. And feel your soul elevate.

Yji23TJArvgJqnACrhD_lA.text: Not anything that stands out, but not anything bad either. Wouldn't come back since there was nothing that I can rave about but I did leave content. The buns are ok but a lot of bun and hardly anything in the inside. Probably better to just source smaller buns. The ramen was good enough and at the table you can add additional sauces in it. Not bad!We also has the chicken skewers - a little dry. Overall, not bad but not great.

ZaOXX_h69iv667WaglE0eg.text: I give this place two stars because of the horrendous service here. The food tastes fine (not the worst but not the best ramen either). 1) I was alone and asked for a table outside. It was a bit out of hours (5 pm or so), and they had plenty of space, but they told me that they would not sit one person outside. They have two person tables, so this really would not have been a big stretch. The only options for people who eat alone are the counter facing the hot kitchen. And it's not possible to even look back to see if there is still light out - the staff keeps asking "if you are done or still want something else". I spent a total of 35 min there including the wait for the food and eating the food. 2) my soup came with practically no broth and I asked for some more. They told me that would be 5 gbp. The entire soup is 12, and am really not sure this is normal. The entire time spent there I felt pressed even though the place was half-empty.That ramen was not worth it.

7BDaSk-KsEzTVb2AAgx8BQ.text: The first time I set foot in a Shoryu restaurant, I was worried that it wouldn't meet my expectations (as I had recently returned from Japan). But as soon as I walked in, there was the familiar smell that instantly reminded me of being in Japan.The greeting, being seated and having the menu explained was all a pleasure. The front of house staff were incredibly welcoming and knowledgeable; there were no questions left unanswered.After a short wait, I was presented with their specialty ramen, the Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu. The bowl itself was a decent portion for the price and as soon as I tucked into the bowl I was seriously hooked. It wasn't as good as Japan, but to be honest, it's the best tonkotsu I've had outside Japan.The Hakata style tonkotsu is properly seasoned and intense, yet balanced in the sense that you can still taste the other elements of the broth, unlike Bone Daddies, where the pork in the broth was simply overpowering and was not at all silky smooth like you'd expect. Shoryu do a splendid job at presenting this style to Londoners. Every component in the bowl has been handled with a lot of love and care. And It shows as soon as you have a mouthful of the stuff.All in all, the service is fantastic. The food and drinks are definitely worth a visit and you'll be satisfied with the price tag. Very well done, Shoryu. I am excited for my next visit.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. Kotteri Hakata ramen, richer and much more intense broth.
Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. The pork belly bun. Remarkably tender and full of flavour.
Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. The Virgin mojito calpico, a splendid and fresh combination.

IdqD-9Y1trubqH0riUfiww.text: This was my first ramen in London!! The stuff were agreeable. Welcome and farewell greeting in Japanese was going on which is quite like a Japanese style. No other Japanese were there including customers except me though.I had a sesami-seasoned spinach(ほうれん草の胡麻和え) for starter and a kimuchi tonkotsu ramen.The spinach one was much closer to authentic Japanese taste than I had expected. It was too sweat for me and lacked soy-sauce taste though.So I added soy source put on a table to eat.(There were chili oil,vinegar and sesami put on a table other than that.)As for the kimchi ramen, the spicy taste overpowered the taste of tonkotsu so I couldn't really enjoy the taste of tonkotsu.I should've ordered the normal one to know this restaurant better.Anyway they offer a good service, a wide range of food menu and sake.It's definitely a nice ramen restaurant unless you expect the authentic Japanese tasty ramen!!There was a small drum put in front of the door.And the stuff beat it once in a while which must be from the intention of creating an Asian atmosphere and catching more attention, but I liked that : )

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. Tonkotsu Kimuchi Ramen

7tHnH7hMygYL71KRl4APsw.text: I had the curry ramen, with shrimp & fried chicken !!!!!!! OMGGGFFFF SOOO GOOD. The ambiance of the restaurant is super nice, their outdoor seating is perfect for people watching and the restaurant has heat lamps! The staff is really awesome, attentive and the food comes out quick ! I would go again but I am leaving for Madrid :)

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom

ZNdgGy76rzTIi6YoOQXIeg.text: Good ramen but a little over 'themed' for my liking. But still highly recommended.The gyoza are some of the best I have had in a while, mainly because the wrapper doesn't over power the filling. The buns are also good. They do need a little more sauce or salt but you have chilli sesame oil and reduced salt soy on the table that you can use to season accordingly. There is a tempura prawn, pork belly, fried chicken or halloumi and mushroom. I'm unsure how Japan halloumi is but I recommend the pork or prawn ones (the prawn one is quite deep fried though so great for a hangover).The ramens have everything you want in a ramen. The tonkotsu bases are my picks. The traditional one is hard to go passed, but the seafood (it still has pork in it) is darn good. Their draught beer selection is all Japanese and perfect soup matches. The wine list is ok but I think beer goes better with this type of food. Every time someone walks in they (mainly the kitchen team) greet you and they also farewell you. There is a lot of 'gong-ing' going on which can get a bit much so try to nab a table outside. It's a really great after work, people watching spot! PS small point: if you get a bench seat on the high tables make sure you are tall as the gap between the table and chair is huge. Gochiso sama deshita.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. Gyoza very delicious wrappers

gpzYa_kkbosYlnXqLRyn3w.text: Well I've been to other Shoryu's but I must say I don't rate the ramen that much. I'm not sure why but it's a bit salty or more bland than any other you would get at say a rival in area. I do however love the sticks...the Wagyu yakitori especially. They seem do stuff like this much better. It's a pity though as ramen is in the name.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom

3qITSFOVsFws-_h9kc76dA.text: I LOVED THIS. I can't seem to get enough ramen. Charlotte, what have you done to me. I was really happy to see that Shoryu has a restaurant in Kingly Court as my office is in that area, so when a friend of mine asked if we could do lunch I was like 'YES YES CAN WE PLEASE GO THERE YES PLEASE AND THANK YOU'. The tonkotsu was delicious, I had the one classed as 'meatier, creamier and richer' in their menu, though I forget the name. It has a 12h broth, 4 slices of pork (on the very fatty side) and double egg. I added to that a splash of soy sauce, and if the pork hadn't been THAT fatty, my experience would have nearly equaled the one I had at Bone Daddies. Nearly. I still preferred Bone Daddie's 20h pork broth tonkotsu, that was just out of this world good. We sat outside, it was the first time I had lunch al fresco in Kingly Court, and I can't wait to do it again. The service was very nice as well, and the food arrived 7 (SEVEN!) minutes after ordering, so I was really happy. And hungry. Again, I forgot to chat whilst I was slurping on that bountiful amount of fatty ramen, so I probably wasn't particularly entertaining to my friend but hey, that's what ramen does to me. OKAY?

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom

8e4J6jwR2Doz7QM4MLNMdg.text: I was craving for ramen when I m walking around so I found this ramen place which I would like to give it a try. I wasn't expecting too much as it's not in Japan. But I found it pretty good I would say. The soup is not too salty and the ramen is tender enough. The only reason I gave 3 stars is because they have MSG in the soup which is a bit cheating. But of course most of the ramen shop does that. I will deff reco this place for ramen lover.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. The ramen here is surprisingly better than I thought

f0SQ7n7iRXwlArHITrLAvw.text: Shoryu is one of the many new, high-quality ramen places taking over London in the wake of Wagamama's slowly fall from grace.  Ramen is the undeniable focus here, along with steamed buns, and they do shine - the broth is thick, tasty and copious enough so you don't feel ripped off, and it won't hit your wallet too hard either.All the Tonkotsu are worth going for, and you won't be disappointed

7P9ueU6Ax5UHLUwKCjfHhg.text: I took my mum here because she had never had Ramen before and I think Kingly Court has a cool atmosphere. Let me just say - my mum is now a Ramen-lover. I've had countless Ramen soups but I really take my hat off to Shoryu. It's perfectly creamy and full of fantastic flavour.The guys next to us ordered frozen beers which are not especially cold but just have frozen froth. We stared at them with interest when they tried to sip their beer. They noticed and said they wouldn't recommend them to us because it's just hard to drink!The high tables are not the most comfortable thing in the world but the long table makes it quite sociable. The waiters are friendly and it's rather fun that they greet you and say goodbye with the sound of a gong and some shouting in Japanese.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. The signature ramen - Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu
Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. The White Natural Ramen Noodles

ZKdztxvO3Dc47QrsAGMHMQ.text: Shoryu ramen is good and consistent. However, it's not exceptional and different. We came when they first had their grand opening promotion (buy one bowl get one free). hubby got the Dracula Tonkotsu and I got the Piri Piri Tonkotsu. Both broths were decent but not as strong as Bone Daddies' broth. Noodles and meat accompaniments  were okay but the portions were smaller than normal. It was more like a snack than a meal. We would go back if they offered another promo.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. Dracula in back and Piri Piri in front

PKUV8jelwqQj8P9kIZBq9Q.text: Shoryu has not disappointed yet. Having been to the Soho branch twice total, Kingly Court is a welcome addition to the chain of high quality ramen restaurants.Consistency is important and this is one thing Shoryu always gets right. Portions are gigantic. I'm not sure exactly what is responsible, but whilst the broth and ingredients don't look much greater in volume than other ramen places, I always leave stuffed. Add some sides into that (their Bao is delicious) and I can hardly walk out the door.Taste wise, it's always a taste explosion in my mouth. I order spicy and get exactly that. There is always the option to add pressed garlic and more chilli on your table. The broth is incredibly flavoursome. Some ramen places, the soup tastes bland and watery. Here it's incredibly rich and you want to finish every drop.Service. This is where Shoryu Soho fell down a bit, being slow to serve, delivering sides after mains etc.. However Shoryu corrected most of that. The only small annoyance on the opening week were multiple staff trying to take your order when it had already been taken. But it's a lot better than previous experience.The Kingly Court branch has a more casual feel due to the small layout and high shared tables. That said, a lot more places are utilising space in this way, and it's not always a bad thing as you can sometimes engage other groups in a friendly chat.Anyway, if you haven't been to Shoryu, what are you waiting for!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. Curry Ramen
Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. Hirata Bun

FSS3CIW8yQZhq9VaPcgHtw.text: After months of my friend going on about this place, I finally went to the one in kingly court and it was so worth it. We ordered two different ramens - both delicious - which were served in a very large, well filled bowl. The starters were also great as were the generous-on-the-alcohol cocktails (which before 7pm only cost £6).Even though the place was busy, the service was quick and efficient and although I wouldn't class it as a bargain, considering the generous portions, good quality of food and service, the pricing is good and this place gets an all-round thumbs up from me!

XYj-8uElHjYHSxht4_Yo7A.text: The space, service and food in Kingly Court Shoryu is better than the one off of Piccadilly if you ask me.  Overall, Shoryu's ramen is ok, not great, but it will take care of your ramen craving just fine.  The hirata buns are delicious and are a must order.  The pricing is also reasonable.Will I go back?  Yes, to this location.

9md1xCFU94BCiQdm8-NXbQ.text: Oh boy I forgot how spicy Piri Piri was. *slurp...take a deep breath...slurp* Heavenly with some light beer in a frosted glass. The ambience of this branch is a bit trendier than their original location at Regent Street. Taste is pretty consistent, and there was no queue for party of one :P. Since it's located at the lovely Kingly Court (especially during Christmas season, all the sparking lights in the courtyard are just delightful), I wouldn't even mind waiting for a bit. Service wasn't as attentive though, probably due to the high volume of traffic.

X4JlPt4QdbXWeS8dLt2E_g.text: YUM! Started off w the pork belly bun and shishito peppers. So good! Also got the sake taster which was a great way to try different sakes. The ramen is delish!! Can't go wrong here. Would have loved to try so many other things but my stomach couldn't handle anymore food.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. Shishito peppers and sake taster
Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. Pork belly buns

HQx-uKH9nMqMHS1Zq3nTWw.text: After my previous disappointing experience at Shoryu I was invited for a complimentary meal to show what improvements have been made since their soft opening. Although this meal was paid for I can honestly say it was there were drastic improvements across all factors that night. And before I start I do want to praise Shoryu for listening to their customers and since I've known them that is all they have been doing. They have at least changed their noodles four times since they first opened, from using the Chinese noodle to the Japanese variety to making their own. Major improvements have been made to their Tonkotsu's broth which I remember started off very salty and now it is one of the richest and fragrant ones I know of in London and perfectly seasoned to my taste all because they are listening.As you can see on my first visit I raised up many concerns and complaints about their meat quality, service and other food quality during their soft opening. But to my surprise they took it all on board professionally and to their advantage to make things better. I was harsh and delivered my disappointment aggressively but received only patience and understanding. Since then they have changed their meat supplier although we were clearly demonstrated that the meat was not raw but because they changed meat supplier which had meat that remained pink even when cooked. But as they could not risk for customers to experience the same shock and to be mistaken they have changed back to their old supplier. To not make this experienced too 'fixed' or prepared we turned up unexpectedly and already the place felt a lot calmer and organised. It would be bias to comment on the service as we did receive extra attention and service but trying to judge upon looking around, everyone seem content. But not once was I made to feel uncomfortable for complaining and was looked after very well.Food was my greatest concern anyway. We asked for a repeat of last visit's order to see if improvements have been made and so we started of with the pork belly hirata buns again. From my photos you can see that the pork is actually visible this time covering a good percentage of the bun. It was a lot more succulent and juicy, just like how I have had it at their other branches. Together with their fluffy airy light buns we very much enjoyed this. With 2-for-1 on hirata buns on Mondays I will be back for this.Our anticipation was finally over when the Tonkotsu arrived. Although there was nothing to fault with my King Tonkotsu on my last order I kept it the same to check on its consistency. And I was glad to have it not disappoint me as the broth was just as rich with depth like how I had it last time. I do enjoy having the free sesame and fresh cloves of garlic available on each seating for self service as I do love my garlic even if it means having garlic breathe after. Luckily for me my boyfriend loves garlic. I also love my sesame. The only slight change were the prawns as they were slightly overcooked compared to last time so lost it's bouncy texture but still it tasted fresh and just a preference of how I like my prawns cooked. Pork was as tender and generous and egg nice and yokey. It was delicious, so much I didn't want it to end.It was such a relieved to see the pork browned as the Karaka Tan Tan Tonkotsu arrived. And when they get this dish right they really do get it right as it was delicious, rich with a good spicy depth to it. The mince pork creates a really nice texture against the noodles because it clings to the noodles so you can the meat taste in every bite. With the crunchy kikurage mushrooms and spring onions which comes in every tonkotsu the dish was a pleasure to devour with a really good bite. We finished on cocktails which were great with more preference towards my Yuzu Mojito which was made unique with the additional umeshu which sweetened it. I found the negroni a bit too bitter compared to others I've had but I'm not an expert to judge further. We were happy to know they have taken aboard the chef at their original branch in Regent's Street which could explain the improvements made. Staff seems to have settled down and I can see it becoming a very successful place in the heart of Carnaby Street as they are the only Japanese restaurant around since Ramen Seto closed down. Great deals are also coming along for more budget diners e.g. their Sunday ramen for £8.95.After this visit and my contentment with their high level of customer service I have given my first poor experience a pass. I will definitely be returning back to try their Kingly specials and can only hope for consistency which I have faith they will be able to deliver.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. King Tonkotsu
Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. Karaka Tantan Noodles
Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. Yusu mojito

otW8WLNUC3b2iBK1tIBpNQ.text: I pinned on my travel map before my husband and I came to London. After a long cold day outside at Cardiff, Wales, we decided to come here for a hot Japanese noodle soup. The wait for dinner was only about an acceptable 20 min on this Tuesday night. We ordered salmon sashimi, soy flavored chicken bun, and sesame tofu as appetizers. We loved them all. We shared a signature hakata tonkotsu, highly recommended by our waitress. It was awesome, soup was thick and flavorful. We concluded with green tea ice cream float and a green tea roll cake. The roll cake was ok. We didn't try the matcha cheesecake but it should be our next thing to try. Thank you Shoryu and your great friendly service!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom

W99nnASh4ci8CedU7Bw2PA.text: This was probably my favorite meal we had in London. I am a big fan of ramen and this place peaked my interest. We got here around 7pm at night. This place was nicely placed in a pretty popular shopping/food center. We walked into this place with no reservation and they asked if we would be okay sitting at the bar, otherwise we would've have to wait . We didn't mind being seated at the bar as this meant we could eat sooner. They rang their gong when we came in. The waitress came over to us and was explaining the ramen and the different menu they had put out for summer. This place also had an option for noodle firmness, to me this is almost unheard of! I ordered the Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu which was recommended by our waitress, and I stuck with the regular futsuu standard of noodle. I also ordered some salmon nigiri. Our food looked delicious when it arrived. I really enjoyed to flavor of the soup and the noodles were cooked just the way I like them. I probably could've gone up a level on noodle firmness, but I enjoyed how they absorbed some of the broth. The salmon nigiri was 8 thick pieces that were pretty good. I would absolutely be back here again if given the opportunity. Though the restaurant was busy we didn't have a lack of water, but the waitress did end up forgetting to come back to us for our order because they ran out of something specific. This didn't really matter to us because we were full by the end anyways.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. Mmmm yumm
Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. Not as pictured when arrived It looked delicious so I ate some and then I remembered to take a picture.

npF8eSdYcDQkSDE4MI-d2Q.text: Amazing ramen. If you need a reasonably priced, healthy meal this place will not disappoint. All of the dishes are beautifully plated in typical Japanese style. We tried the chicken, and pork buns. Both good, but a little heavy on the mayo (I recommend you ask for lite mayo). The enochi butter mushroom appetizer is very good and has a delicious sauce. The ginger salmon is tempura fried and the dipping sauce is unfortunately mayonnaise. We loved all 3 ramens we ordered, the shoryu ganso tonkotsu, miso wafu chicken, and the white natural. Be warned that the wafu chicken is fried. The broth on all the soups is rich and nourishing. Your body will thank you.My only gripe is cleanliness of tables (sticky) and floors in the courtyard (lots of spilled ramen).

NuG9_3eCKX9KE9LoCtBO7A.text: Shoryu is located in the amazing Kingly Court which is a specific area that contains many restaurants and other businesses plus lights and the design of the area is very eye catching. There was a short wait when we went there and you can put your phone number down so that it will update you on your current queue in line. I didnt mind the wait since the area has so much to see and explore. I tried the pork belly bun, takoyakis and the black garlic oil ramen. Pork belly bun was great better than the deep fried chicken bun my friend had and the black garlic oil ramen was alright. I liked how they provide fresh garlic on the table and you can use a garlic crusher to add it into your bowl of ramen. The star of the night was definitely the takoyakis, it was way better than some of the places i tried in Norcal and Socal. My friend said it is comparable to the takoyakis in Japan.We went there around 6 something PM but when we were leaving there is a line of people waiting to be seated.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. I forgot to take a picture before digging in. I was very hungry.

e0gE9OfCIoIoypPNSYwN7Q.text: Ugh--I love ramen and this place bastardized my favorite kind of food.Bring on the ramen +'s:+ Only the egg was decent. Cooked perfectly but had no seasoning.+ Ramen itself is chewy and cooked correctly.Check please -'s:- Took one slurp of the broth and was horrified. I have had my share of excellent ramen from Tokyo to New York to San Francisco. F!! The broth at Shoryu was poor. I could not taste anything in it. It was so watered down I dumped soy sauce into my bowl. It was a dump--not a douse--to get some flavor.- Nothing else was in this bowl. Yes I saw the strips of dried seaweed and the fatty pork was fine but nothing else really filled the bowl.- Price. I hate paying for a bowl that I have to fix.Overall we came here because we had no reservations in London on a Saturday night. We grabbed this seating because it was the only place that would take us without reservations. If you are starving and have nowhere else to go, then this place will work.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. Extra egg and meatier broth for GBP 12.50

zfxDL-d0NTrNVX-YY1hBRQ.text: Its my 3 or 4 time having ramen at this place. Its located in a small courtyard that is absolutely cute :) the food and atmosphere is great. The food is spicy just like we like it don't complain if the food is to spicy lol

XRMhbmxV_U2JZLF2QaWNmg.text: I love a bowl of ramen, and this place serves up one delicious bowl of it.  It's tucked away in a cute little courtyard full of restaurants, and it's a very nice little area to meet people in. I shared a bowl of the Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu Ramen with my son (although I probably should have just ordered two!).  The pork was tasty and very tender.  All the extra goodies inside, including the egg were just right.  The broth was rich, salty and delicious.  I ordered the noodles as "normal" (vs chewy) and it suited me well.  It's loaded with garlic (and there is a bulb of garlic on the table along with a garlic crusher - if you want more).  My husband ordered the Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu Ramen, which had the same stuff inside, but the broth was richer (also a very good bowl of ramen!).  We saw a flyer for the Shoryu Bun Wagyu, so we got two of those.  The steamed buns were huge, but it was too much bread for the little amount of wagyu in it.  It was also advertised as something like "even softer bun", but I actually found it to be too airy and soft - smaller and a bit more dense would have been more suitable.  We also had Edamame, which was standard, and a few drinks.  We'll be back on future trips, but I'll skip the side orders and will go straight for the Ramen.For the Ramen, I give it 5 stars.  For the Shoryu Bun and slow service (all slow - except the bowl of ramen came pretty quickly) I will bring them down to 4 stars.  If you are a Ramen lover, I highly recommend seeking this place out!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. Edamame and Shoryu Bun Wagyu
Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu Ramen

6itD-WIdi7X7bx1MlozGsQ.text: Eating at this Shoryu location was one of the best experiences I have had. It is in a great area and has a large space for dining, so there was no wait even during the lunch rush. Regarding the quality of the food, it was fantastic. Every component within the Ramen bowl was done very well. I also liked how you can choose the texture of your noodles (soft, medium, hard). Additionally, I ordered a prawn bun and bbq chicken bun, both were pretty good. But the ramen stole the show. The part that was most impressive to me was that our food literally came out in 4 minutes after ordering. The combination of quality of food, service, and atmosphere made my Shoryu experience awesome. The only reason I do not give 5 stars is that I went to another Shoryu location a week later and it wasn't nearly as good there, which was disappointing.

txb8umBrEOmCqWf2588Ieg.text: I told myself I would stop giving out 5 stars but then Shoryu came along and kind of blew me away so 5 stars for you Shoryu!I got the Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu which has fried shallots on it. After mixing my ramen around a bit I could barely see the shallots but oh, you can taste them! The broth was great, the noodles were great, the toppings went well, the pork was so tender! I was the first one to finish. My only complaint was that the shape of my spoon didn't allow me to scoop all the broth out of the bowl. I thought the portion was small at first but after eating it all I can say it was a good portion (gosh I'm full)Cool atmosphere in Kingly Court (we ate in the restaurant though) and nice staff. Would definitely recommend

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu

3BVYUrQ6jTxRrtd4wY78Lw.text: So, there are times that I've been to places and they really suck. In those cases I either try them again (not likely) or I just don't write a review about them, because you never know- maybe they were having a rough day... ammiright? Just being fair. In this case, I've only been to Shoryu Ramen in Carnaby once and it blew my freaking mind. Like, mouth orgasms multiple times, lots of noises, probably some of the best ramen I've ever had. Maybe it had something to do with the time of day and how the moon was lined up with the sun. I don't know. Anyway, in the case of fairness, this place gets 4 stars, because I think I need to go back and try it again before giving 5. Just being fair. So, my husband and I got the Curry Ramen and The Original (minus the meat, but with pork broth), and the shrimp tempura bun and haloumi cheese and mushroom bun. Those buns were so good. Seriously, the bread was just perfect and the insides were so flavorful and the right amount of crunchy and soft. Holy momma mia I loved those buns. They had just a small amount of sauce that added the perfect amount of flavor. And then the ramen. So flavorful and amazing. Both broths were completely different and unique. Very very good. I'm gonna come back to try their veggie ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. Cheese and mushroom
Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. Shrimp tempura

U_Nzi-8bQk0BBOl84vEobg.text: This is my 2nd visit and it was pretty successful because this time I got to try the classic tonkotsu.I liked it - I don't think it's the best I've ever had but it was tasty and pleasantly flavourful without being too fatty.I also tried their dumplings - very goodtheir seaweed salad - excellentand their buns - the bun was a bit stodgy and I'm not sure about the prawn combo.All in all, it's a solid spot for ramen, although I'd like to go to Bone Daddies soon and compare since it's been a while!

Z27HPdSFOb3JBPMlTkoREw.text: Don't bother. Ordered the katsu curry and it was vile. The chicken portion was the size of a thumb. And the tables were filthy and full of used bowls plates and trays, the staff overworked. Overpriced substandard service and food. Shame on the Japanese centre for allowing this.

2o8qQWA6xD9VhEcYoP1Eig.text: I love a good ramen on a chilly day. Sadly, Shoryu wasn't what I was looking for. They used what I'd like to called the "soggy" noodles for their ramen. They are made from whole wheat and that's why there's no bounce to eat when you sipped up that noodles. If you like the bouncy , chewy texture for your noodles, you want to look for a ramen that serves "egg noodles" for their ramen. The soggy ramen noodles was a huge turn off for me that I couldn't even enjoy the hot soup.

m0eTXNY9yytaucW_OcjgmA.text: 3.5 stars.Pretty good ramen in a cool spot in London. There is a beautiful open courtyard (with heaters!) with tons of restaurants, and Shoryu happens to be one of them.The restaurant itself is quite small, but we managed to get some seats at the bar. If there is tan tan ramen on the menu, that is always my default. I love tonkotsu broth with some chili and minced pork. This one packed quite a bit of heat compared to other tan tan ramens I've had, but it still hit the spot. Extra items come out separately vs. in your ramen. There's a whole garlic bulb with a garlic press on the table if you want to add any- it would be nice if it was already pre-pressed for convenience.Happy hour drink specials Monday-Thursday from 5-7pm. Mondays are BOGO buns with the purchase of ramen.

pL6yiP0M_jhEblbcNi7J9Q.text: Poor service.  very very slow service.the salmon sasimi is not that fresh as i had in Cocoro.the bun is okso does Ramen, not that good as Cocoro.bad expeience , never come again.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom

dlsAi5esK2xL9FySX0HQQQ.text: I've been going to this branch of Shoryu for four years and unfortunately it's been a consistent decline in service and quality. The servers used to be a great part of the experience but there have been multiple instances where one waitress has been consistently rude to different people that I've gone with and others have been quite slow to help and forget what we've asked for (even when we ask three times). The food is often a hit or miss - sometimes it's just the right thing for a cold day in London but other times it's barely ok. I'd advise to go to another branch if at all!

OjMZxTrhVlgSaSQJxysbdw.text: I got the origin (original?) ramen. It's not half bad - the broth is decent, flavourful and not too salty. However, the pork belly that came with my noodle is just not good.Which sucks for me...since I also got the pork belly bun (skip this).

q1yyaSoSvWYy8EtcSOyvfA.text: Ramen has been off my menu for a few years - for no good reason - and I'm so glad Shoryu reintroduced this delectable dish to my menu!My flatmate suggested we dine here for lunch and I could kiss her for the recommendation! Speedy service, and seating even though they were busy - it only took 5minutes before they found us a comfortable window seat (perfect for people watching and girlie catching up). The menu leaves nothing to be desired, with an excellent range of ramen, sides and contemporary/traditional dishes.Naturally it being the weekend, we decided to accompany our meal with one of their Tokyo Autumn inspired cocktails. Spice lovers I would definitely recommend the 'Wake Me Up in Tokyo' a delicious fresh cocktail with added chilli to give it a little kick - Seriously tasty! Wanting to try something different I opted for the Karaka Tan Tan Tonkotsu - tonkotsu with a twist - rich & spicy minced pork marinated in white miso, garlic and chiu chow chilli oil (no char siu barbecue pork belly, no sesame). Amazing! Just the right level of spicy to give it a kick but not too subtle on the flavour. Served in authentic deep dish bowls, I struggled to finish all of this - seriously felt like it was a bottomless bowl!It would have been rude for us to leave without sampling at least one other of the Autumn signature cocktails (it's was Saturday, don't judge ;) ). We left our meal feeling extremely satisfied and suitably stuffed!Five stars happily awarded for this Ramen joint, thanks for reminding me what a great dish ramen is - can't wait to return!

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom

1-6L-Hmwmc-RgJ2xyYIcDQ.text: I actually enjoyed my wafu chicken ramen but the service was dismal.The idiot at the front whose sole job was to seat people tried unsuccessfully twice to seat us at shared tables in seats already allocated to other diners.  The one empty table, with a bowl of ramen sitting empty, was apparently on hold while the diner went to the loo, which wasn't the case at all.  I can't go into more detail as it would surely bore you to read as much as it would me to type, but take my word this boob was a massive pain.Other service was bad - obviously not well run and our server seemed very unhappy working. Also, food took forever - like 35 minutes for a bowl of soup. Wafu chicken ramen was tasty, tho the chicken a bit dry and needed salt badly.A bit expensive for poor service and ok noodle soup.  Oh well, at least the company was spot on.

4HO2jLYm-X-JWaxkqRSIRg.text: Great service, and the ramen was solid. Good for vegetarians who like ramen. They have two miso ramens which can sometimes be hard to find.

myq77TgfYUZk2vmy2u8A7g.text: Literally the best Ramen I have ever had. I really recommend their signature dish, each bite surprises you with a new flavour. Especially if you like pork, pork belly this will delight you. Wow, can't wait to come back.

photos.caption: Photo of Shoryu - London, United Kingdom. Literally the best Ramen I have ever had. This is their signature dish, each bite surprises you with a new flavour.
